examples.text: Löylyssä ei ole hyvä istua kerralla viittätoista minuuttia enempää.
examples.english: One shouldn't sit in the heat of the sauna for more than fifteen minutes at a time.
Could you throw some water (on the stove)?
Let's go back to the (heat of) sauna!

examples.text: Hyvää löylyä voi Pekka Tommilan mielestä kuvailla kymmenillä adjektiiveilla.
examples.ref: 23 July 2011, “Hyvä löyly syntyy kivistä”, in YLE, retrieved 2018-07-12
examples.english: According to Pekka Tommila, a good heat of a sauna can be described with dozens of adjectives.

glosses: the steam that rises from the sauna stove (kiuas) or the heat of the sauna

examples.english: That was one good sauna bath!

examples.text: Miltä tuntuvat löylyt maailman ainoassa maailmanpyöräsaunassa?
examples.ref: 1 July 2017, Anu Punkari, “Miltä tuntuvat löylyt maailman ainoassa maailmanpyöräsaunassa? MTV Uutiset mukana testaamassa”, in MTV, retrieved 2018-07-12
examples.english: How does it feel like to take a sauna bath in the world's only Ferris wheel sauna?

glosses: sauna bath, sauna (act of taking a bath in a sauna)

to turn up the heat on an advertising campaign

examples.text: Kiu­as­val­mis­ta­ja Harvia aikeissa hakea lisää löylyä pörs­si­lis­tau­tu­mi­sel­la
examples.ref: 5 March 2018, “Kiu­as­val­mis­ta­ja Harvia aikeissa hakea lisää löylyä pörs­si­lis­tau­tu­mi­sel­la”, in Kaleva, retrieved 2018-07-12
examples.english: Sauna stove manufacturer Harvia intending to turn up the heat by listing on stock exchange

list of meronyms in the Finnish entry for

words.etymology_text: From Proto-Finnic *leülü, from Proto-Finno-Ugric *lewle (“spirit, soul”). Cognate with Estonian leil, Komi-Permyak лов (lov), Udmurt лул (lul), Northern Sami lievla and Hungarian lélek (“soul, ghost”).

raw_glosses: (dialectal) birch bolete, scaber stalk mushroom, (Leccinum scabrum)
glosses: birch bolete, scaber stalk mushroom, (Leccinum scabrum)

words.etymology_text: A Karelian dialectal word related to Karelian löpö, löpöi. Possibly from löpöttää (“to hang, flap”) due to its spongy meat.
Sound-symbolic; compare Karelian löpšöi, Veps lopэi

examples.text: Muistona tuolta ajalta on ensimmäinen kuparityöni: tehtävänä oli pakottaa kuparilevystä löylykauha saunaan.
examples.ref: 2014, Maarit Tyrkkö, Tyttö ja nauhuri, WSOY
examples.english: A keepsake from those days is my first job in copper: the assignment was to forge a scoop for the sauna from copper plate.

examples.text: Hänkin rupesi riisumaan vaatteitaan ja luikahti saunan puolelle, jossa Osku jo odotteli löylykauha kädessä - An mennä vaan! Jaska istui lauteille Oskun viereen ja pani kyynärpäät polvilleen huomatessaan, että kohta kihahtaa ja kovaa.
examples.ref: 2008, Aulis Murto, Mannakorven markkinoilla, BoD - Books on Demand, page 109
examples.english: He started undressing too and slipped to the sauna room, where Osku was already waiting scoop in hand. - Go ahead then! Jaska sat on the seat beside Osku and put his elbows on his knees, noticing that soon it will sizzle hard.

glosses: A scoop for throwing water on the sauna stove.

examples.english: I/She/Someone found the manual behind the appliance. / The manual turned up behind the appliance.
We/I can't find the manual anywhere. / The manual is nowhere to be found.
The missing child was found at the playground.

raw_glosses: (intransitive) to find, be found, be discovered, turn up
glosses: to find, be found, be discovered, turn up

examples.english: There's even an original printed manual.

examples.text: Tätä paitaa löytyy näissä kolmessa värissä.
examples.english: This shirt comes in these three colors.

raw_glosses: (intransitive, colloquial, Sveticism) there is/are, to exist, come

examples.english: I found it in the garage.
I found him sleeping.

raw_glosses: (transitive) to find; to discover; to come across (in = elative/ablative, doing = elative of the third infinitive)
glosses: to find; to discover; to come across (in = elative/ablative, doing = elative of the third infinitive)

words.etymology_text: From Proto-Finnic *leütädäk, from Proto-Finno-Ugric *lewδä- (“to find”), or alternatively borrowed from Proto-Germanic *hleutaną, which is itself of uncertain origin.
